newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil's Safras sees 26.38 mln tonne soybean crop.
newsitem.headline: Brazil's Safras sees 26.38 mln tonne soybean crop.

text.p: Brazil's 1996/97 soybean crop should reach 26.38 million tonnes, up from 23.29 million tonnes in 1995/96, said independent consultants Safras e Mercado.
Planted area is expected to total 11.52 million hectares against 10.87 million hectares planted last year and a harvested area of 10.76 million hectares.
Parana should retain its place at the top of the production league, with forecast output of 6.7 million tonnes, up from last year's 6.45 million tonnes.

Rio Grande do Sul, which traditionally is the largest producing state but which was hit by a prolonged drought last year, should produce six million tonnes, staging a strong recovery from last year's 4.4 million tonnes, Safras predicted.

Mato Grosso, where farmers had feared a sharp reduction in output due to severe credit problems, should see output of 4.98 million tonnes, actually higher than the 4.65 million tonnes produced in 1995/96, Safras said.
"The increase in supply should be compensated to a large extent by good demand prospects, both internally and for export," Safras e Mercado said in its weekly newsletter.
"For this reason, it is possible to imagine a favorable price scenario for the 1997/98 marketing year (February/January), albeit probably below the excellent levels seen in 1996/97," it added.
In its first full estimate for the 1996/97 crop, Safras also revised slightly upwards its figure for 1995/96 from previous forecasts of 23.05 million tonnes.

This is because of higher production than earlier anticipated in Parana where previously Safras had put the crop at 6.43 million tonnes and also in Mato Grosso where output last year had earlier been plotted at 4.44 million tonnes.
Production forecasts in thousand of tonnes by state for 1996/97 and 1995/96 are as follows.
-- Caroline Bulloch, Rio de Janeiro newsroom, 5521 5074151
